1.text: Decide what kind of meat you'd like to use.

2.text: If necessary, trim off any excess fat, tendons, or meat.

3.text: For larger cuts of meat, consider stabbing the meat with a prong for better salt coverage.

4.text: Decide whether you want to cure with a pre-mixed curing salt or mix your own.

5.text: Use a ratio of 2:1000 sodium nitrite and salt, if mixing your own curing salt.

6.text: Mix up your spices along with your curing salt.

7.text: With your hands, rub the curing salt and spice mix over the entire cut of meat.

8.text: Refrigerate the meat for 7 to 10 days.

9.text: After 7 to 10 days, remove from the refrigerator and rinse off all the salt/spice mix.

11.text: Wrap the meat in tightly cheesecloth.

12.text: to help it keep its shape while it ages (optional).

13.text: Label the meat and hang in a cool, dark place for anywhere from two weeks to two months.

17.text: Place your meat in a brining bag.

18.text: In the refrigerator, brine your meat one day for every two pounds of meat.

19.text: Rinse the cured meat thoroughly in fresh cold water to get rid of the crystallized salt on the surface of the meat.

20.text:
Set the meat on a wire mesh screen to drain for 24 hours in a well ventilated area and store in the refrigerator [9]
